nominalpy.objects package

Submodules

nominalpy.objects.component module

class nominalpy.objects.component.Component(credentials: Credentials, id: str)

Bases: Object

The Component class is a base object that can be attached to the simulation or to other objects within the simulation. Components have messages that can store data.

get_message(name: str) → Message

Returns a message with a particular name, if it exists, on the object. If the message does not exist, it will return a None object. The message is a wrapper for data stored on components.

Parameters:

name (str) – The name of the message as a parameter on the component

Returns:

The message reference that exists from the message in the parameter

Return type:

Message

messages: list = []

Defines a list of messages associated with this component. Any new requested message will be added here.

nominalpy.objects.entity module

class nominalpy.objects.entity.Entity(credentials: Credentials, id: str)

Bases: object

The Entity class contains some basic parameters for storing the public API credentials of the current session along with a unqique identifier for this entity. It has not functionality and is inherited from a number of actual simulation objects.

id: str = None

Defines the unique GUID identifier of the object. This needs to be in the correct GUID format.

nominalpy.objects.message module

class nominalpy.objects.message.Message(credentials: Credentials, id: str)

Bases: Object

The Message class is able to store a series of parameters and data associated with the particular message type. The message is also able to be subscribed to a database and data can be fetched from the database system to pull back message data over the simulation time.

fetch(*values) → list

This method fetches the data, in the form of a JSON array, from the database assuming that it has been subscribed to the database system. The returned data will include a time stamp and the JSON data of the message at that time.

Parameters:

values (list) – An optional set of parameters as a list that can filter the data

Returns:

A list containing all data time-stamped from the database

Return type:

list

fetch_df(*values) → DataFrame

Fetch the data from the simulation and return the results as a pandas DataFrame for easy handling and analysis.

Parameters:

values (list) – An optional set of parameters as a list that can filter the data

Returns:

A dataframe containing the values of the subscribed messages for the simulation

Return type:

pandas.DataFrame

fetch_range(min_time: float, max_time: float, *values) → list

This method fetches the data, in the form of a JSON array, from the database assuming that it has been subscribed to the database system. The returned data will include a time stamp and the JSON data of the message at that time. This method also takes in a filter of the minimum and maximum simulation time in seconds to search for.

Parameters:

  • min_time (float) – The minimum time in simulation seconds to pull the data from the database

  • max_time (float) – The maximum time in simulation seconds to pull the data from the database

  • values (list) – An optional set of parameters as a list that can filter the data

Returns:

A list containing all data time-stamped within the range

Return type:

list

classmethod message_fetch(credentials: Credentials, simulation: str, id: str, *values) → list

This method fetches the data, in the form of a JSON array, from the database assuming that it has been subscribed to the database system. The returned data will include a time stamp and the JSON data of the message at that time. This is a class level method and takes in some credentials and an ID of the message, rather than being an object level method.

Parameters:

  • credentials (Credentials) – The API credentials to correctly call the simulation

  • simulation (str) – The simulation unique ID in a GUID format

  • id (str) – The unique ID of the message to fetch in a GUID format

  • values (list) – An optional set of parameters as a list that can filter the data

Returns:

A list containing all data time-stamped from the database

Return type:

list

classmethod message_fetch_range(credentials: Credentials, simulation: str, id: str, min_time: float, max_time: float, *values) → list

This method fetches the data, in the form of a JSON array, from the database assuming that it has been subscribed to the database system. The returned data will include a time stamp and the JSON data of the message at that time. This method also takes in a filter of the minimum and maximum simulation time in seconds to search for. This is a class level method and takes in some credentials and an ID of the message, rather than being an object level method.

Parameters:

  • credentials (Credentials) – The API credentials to correctly call the simulation

  • simulation (str) – The simulation unique ID in a GUID format

  • id (str) – The unique ID of the message to fetch in a GUID format

  • min_time (float) – The minimum time to fetch data from the database from in seconds

  • max_time (float) – The maximum time to fetch data from the database from in seconds

  • values (list) – An optional set of parameters as a list that can filter the data

Returns:

A list containing all data time-stamped from the database

Return type:

list

subscribe(interval: float = 10.0) → bool

This method will subscribe the message to the database system and ensure that the data is stored over time. The interval specifies the time in seconds between recordings of the data in the database.

Parameters:

interval (float) – The simulation second interval that the data should be stored in the database

Returns:

A successful subscription flag if the message is now logged to the database

Return type:

bool

nominalpy.objects.object module

class nominalpy.objects.object.Object(credentials: Credentials, id: str, api_type: str = 'object')

Bases: Entity

The Object class represents an object within the simulation. Objects can have data that can be set and returned. This wrapper ensures that all data is cached and updated when required. Cached data is fetched on an API call and if no simulation events have occurred, the data is not fetched again.

delete() → bool

This method will delete the current object from the simulation and remove access to all objects associated with this.

Returns:

A successful deletion operation flag

Return type:

bool

get_type() → str

This method returns the full simulation type class name, including the namespace of the object. This requires a call to fetch the object.

Returns:

The full simulation type of the object from the simulation

Return type:

str

get_value(param: str) → str

This method returns the JSON data associated with the parameter passed in at the current time in the simulation.

Parameters:

param (str) – A parameter on the object to fetch the JSON data for

Returns:

The JSON data for a particular parameter on the object

Return type:

str

get_values(*values) → dict

This method returns a JSON dictionary of parameters passed within the function. The values can be a set of parameter names to fetch and the JSON data associated with the object’s data will be returned at the current simulation time.

Parameters:

values (list) – A list of parameters within the object to search for

Returns:

A dictionary of parameter values in the order they were specified in

Return type:

dict

set_value(param: str, value: str) → bool

This method attempts to set a particular parameter to a particular value, provided that the value is in the correct JSON format. If the parameter name or the value is incorrect, the value will not be set and return a failure.

Parameters:

  • param (str) – The parameter name of the value to update in the object

  • value (str) – The correct JSON formatted value of the parameter that should be set

Returns:

A successful setting of the parameter and associated value

Return type:

bool

set_values(**kwargs) → bool

This method sets a series of parameters on the object based on a dictionary keyword argument set. Any number of parameters can be set. If the values are incorrect, then the parameter will not be set.

Parameters:

kwargs (dict) – A set of keyword arguments for applying data to the object parameters

Returns:

A successful setting of all values passed in

Return type:

bool

nominalpy.objects.simulation module

class nominalpy.objects.simulation.Simulation(credentials: Credentials, reset: bool = True)

Bases: Entity

The Simulation class allows for a simulation to be constructed using the API and for objects to be added to the simulation. All objects need to be created via the simulation and the simulation can also tick all objects within the simulation.

add_component(type: str, owner: Component = None, **kwargs) → Component

Attempts to add a new component to the simulation. This component can be added to an owner, if the owning component is passed in, or it can be added to the simulation as the base type. Additionally, initialisation parameters can be passed in to set on create with the keyword arguments. If the component is invalid or the type is incorrect, a None component will be returned. Otherwise, a component will be initialised with the ID from the call.

Parameters:

  • type (str) – The full simulation type that the object will be created of

  • owner (Component) – The component that will own the component and will be attached to, if it exists

  • kwargs (dict) – A set of keyword arguments and parameters to initialse the object’s data to when created

Returns:

A reference to the component added initialised with the correct ID

Return type:

Component

capture_image(file_name: str, spacecraft: Object, fov: float = 90.0, exposure: float = 0.0, ray_tracing: bool = False, size: tuple = (500, 500), camera_position: dict = None, camera_rotation: tuple = (0, 0, 0), cesium: bool = False, timeout: float = 3.0) → bool

Attempts to capture an image of the simulation using the visualisation tool. This will capture an image based on a component’s position and attitude. The visualiser will only capture the image if it has been initialised and enabled for the user account.

Parameters:

  • file_name (str) – The name of the file to save the image as when the data is received

  • spacecraft (Object) – The spacecraft object to capture the image from with it’s position

  • fov (float) – The field of view of the camera in degrees

  • exposure (float) – The camera exposure levels with a base level of 0

  • ray_tracing (bool) – A flag whether ray-tracing on the camera is enabled

  • size (tuple) – A tuple containing the X and Y pixel size of the image as (X, Y)

  • camera_position (dict) – The JSON formatted position of the camera relative to the base object as X, Y, Z

  • camera_rotation (dict) – A tuple containing pitch, roll and yaw angle values in degrees of the camera relative to the base object

  • cesium (bool) – A flag whether Cesium is enabled. Cesium must have been configured before this can be enabled

  • timeout (float) – A timeout for pausing the thread waiting for an image. If the timeout is <= 0, it will run asynchronously

Returns:

A successful capture flag if the request was sent correctly

Return type:

bool

confiure_cesium(access_token: str, terrain_id: int = 1, imagery_id: int = 2) → None

Configures Cesium within the imagery system to capture photos using a Cesium account. The access token must be valid or the imagery request will not work correctly.

Parameters:

  • access_token (str) – The valid Cesium access token that exists within a user’s account

  • terrain_id (int) – The asset ID of the terrain map chosen for the Cesium object

  • imagery_id (int) – The asset ID of the imagery asset chosen for the Ceisum object

get_component_types() → list

This will return a list of all component types available in the simulation that can be created. This includes components, component models and simulation subsystems. This will include the full name of every component inside a list.

Returns:

A list of all component types available in the simulation

Return type:

list

get_message_types() → list

This will return a list of all message types available in the simulation that can be created. This will include the full name of every message inside a list.

Returns:

A list of all simulation message types that are valid within the simulation

Return type:

list

get_planet_message(planet: str) → Message

Returns the current planet state from the simulation by fetching the data from the SPICE kernels via the Universe system.

Parameters:

planet (str) – The name of the planet whose state message will be returned

Returns:

The Message object containing the SPICE planet state message

Return type:

Message

get_system(type: str, **kwargs) → Object

Fetches a particular simulation system that is valid from the simulation and returns it as an object.

Parameters:

  • type (str) – The full simulation type that the system will be searched for

  • kwargs (dict) – A set of keyword arguments and parameters to initialse the systems’ data to when created

Returns:

The object reference to the simulation system that is found

Return type:

Object

get_time() → float

Returns the current simulation time based on the number of seconds that have been ticked.

Returns:

The current time of the simulation in seconds

Return type:

float

reset() → None

Deletes and resets the simulation. All components, data and messages associated with the timeline on the simulation will be deleted.

tick(step: float = 0.001, iterations: int = 1) → None

Attempts to tick the simulation by a certain amount. This will tick the simulation with some step size, in the form of a time span, and the iterations. The iterations are ticked on the simulation side and will tick with the same step size.

Parameters:

  • step (float) – The step-size to tick the simulation in seconds

  • iterations (int) – The number of iterations to run the simulation at
